name: U.S. Government Quiz: American Presidents | 15 Questions

questions.text: What first name has been most common among presidents?
questions.explanation:
James.

	There have been x6 James, x4 John, x4 William, and x3 George.

questions.text: Which president was the sixth to be named James?
questions.explanation:
James Carter & Carter.

	James Earl Carter was better known as Jimmy Carter.

questions.text: Name one of five 20th Century presidents who went by names other than the one they were born with; that is, their birth name is completely different, different last name, or they went by their middle name rather than their first. Hint: Adult last name only
questions.explanation:
Clinton & Ford & Eisenhower & Wilson & Coolidge.

	Ford was born Leslie King, Jr. Clinton was born William Jefferson Blythe III.  Eisenhower was born David Dwight Eisenhower, but it was soon changed to Dwight David Eisenhower.  Wilson was born Thomas Woodrow Wilson, but dropped the Thomas later so that his full name was simply Woodrow Wilson.  President Grant, a 19th century president, was born Hiram Ulysses Grant. However, when Grant was 17, Congressman Hamer nominated him to West Point. He mistakenly wrote down Grant's name as "Ulysses S. Grant of Ohio", and this became his adopted name. His nickname became "Sam" among colleagues at West Point, since the initials "U.S." also stood for "Uncle Sam", a personification that represented the United States in political cartoons from the early 19th century to today.  Coolidge was born John Calvin Coolidge, but was called 'Calvin' from childhood.

questions.text: There have been 5 pairs of presidents with the same last name. Which two were not related?
questions.explanation:
Andrew and Lyndon Johnson.

	The Harrisons were grandfather and grandson, the Adams were father and son, and the Roosevelts are 5th cousins.

questions.text: Which president was not given a state funeral, but was buried with a Confederate flag draped on his coffin?
questions.explanation:
John Tyler.

	Years after he served as president, he joined the Confederacy and was buried with his casket draped in a Confederate flag.

questions.text: Who was the first president who was subject to the term limitations of the 22nd Amendment to the US Constitution (maximum of two terms)?
questions.explanation:
Dwight D. Eisenhower

	It was passed in 1951, and was phrased as to not apply to whomever was serving as president when it was ratified. That president was Truman (who decided not to run anyway).

questions.text: Who was the only president to be elected to the presidency twice immediately after serving as vice president?
questions.explanation:
Thomas Jefferson.

	Bush was the opposite: twice elected VP and once president. Reagan was never VP. Nixon was elected president twice, and had served as VP, but there were 8 years between his presidency and his vice presidency.

questions.text: Who was the second president to be assassinated?
questions.explanation:
James A. Garfield

	Garfield died two months after being shot. Lincoln was the 3rd to die, the 1st assassinated. McKinley was the 3rd assassinated, the 5th to die in office. Harding was 6th to die in office, but he was not assassinated.

questions.text: What US president returned to public service as the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court?
questions.explanation:
William Howard Taft.

	After his presidency, Taft served as Professor of Law at Yale until President Harding made him Chief Justice of the United States, a position he held until just before his death in 1930. To Taft, the appointment was his greatest honor -- he wrote: "I don't remember that I ever was President."

questions.text: What president served two non-consecutive terms?
questions.explanation:
Grover Cleveland & Cleveland.

	Just had to ask it.

questions.text: Who was the only president never to marry?
questions.explanation:
James Buchanan.

	Buchanan was engaged at one point, but his fiance committed suicide before they married.

questions.text: What president was never elected to the post?
questions.explanation:
Gerald Ford.

	Slightly tricky: none of the choices initially became president by being elected to the post. But Johnson, Truman, and Coolidge were elected to successive terms after their 'accidental' term. Ford was the only one to succeed to the presidency not by the death of his predecessor, but by his (Nixon's) resignation.

questions.text: Who had the shortest term as president?
questions.explanation:
William Harrison.

	Harrison died about a month after his inauguration. He gave the longest inauguration speech ever, in a cold rain. It is speculated that doing this led to the pneumonia that eventually killed him. Garfield served about half a year before dying from his surgeons attempts to remove a bullet he got on July 2, 1881. Roosevelt died less than 3 months after his inauguration, but it was his 4th, actually making his term as president the longest. McKinley had served one full term before being killed half a year into his second term.

questions.text: Who was the youngest man to serve as president?
questions.explanation:
Theodore Roosevelt.

	Kennedy was the youngest elected; Roosevelt the youngest to serve.

questions.text: What president was once president of a labor union?
questions.explanation:
Ronald Reagan.

	Ronald Reagan was president of the Screen Actors Guild.
